HL7 Standard.summary: This IG is fundamentally based on FHIR for representing and exchanging HAI reports. It leverages FHIR's Questionnaire and QuestionnaireResponse resources, extending US Core profiles. While it acknowledges CDA and provides mappings for interoperability, CDA is not central to its core approach. v2 and v3 are not directly relevant to this IG's purpose.

Geographic Scope.summary: This Implementation Guide focuses on standardizing the electronic submission of Healthcare Associated Infection (HAI) reports to the National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN) of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in the United States. It leverages US Core profiles and defines specific constraints for HAI reporting, indicating a national scope within the United States.

Domain Focus.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide focuses on standardizing the electronic submission of Healthcare Associated Infection (HAI) reports to the CDC's National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN). It primarily leverages FHIR Questionnaires and QuestionnaireResponses to model NHSN forms and their completed responses, utilizing US Core profiles and NHSN-specific value sets. The IG's core purpose is to facilitate public health surveillance and quality improvement related to HAIs by enabling interoperable data exchange between healthcare systems and the NHSN.

Implementers.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide focuses on standardizing the electronic submission of Healthcare Associated Infection (HAI) reports to the CDC's National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN). It primarily involves EHR systems for data collection and Public Health Systems for receiving and analyzing the reports. Other systems play a smaller role, mainly in providing data that feeds into the EHR.

Users & Stakeholders.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide (IG) primarily focuses on enabling healthcare systems to electronically submit Healthcare Associated Infection (HAI) reports to the CDC's National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN). The design is driven by the need for standardized, interoperable data exchange between healthcare facilities and public health agencies for surveillance and quality improvement. While clinical care teams provide the source data, the IG's design is primarily influenced by the requirements of public health agencies and the developers implementing the data exchange. Patients and caregivers are not directly involved, and the role of payers and research organizations is minimal.
